Nuxt Kit provides a set of utilities to help you create and use pages. You can use these utilities to manipulate the pages configuration or to define route rules.
In Nuxt 3, routes are automatically generated based on the structure of the files in the

directory. However, there may be scenarios where you'd want to customize these routes. For instance, you might need to add a route for a dynamic page not generated by Nuxt, remove an existing route, or modify the configuration of a route. For such customizations, Nuxt 3 offers the
feature, which allows you to extend and alter the pages configuration.
Watch Vue School video about extendPages.
language-ts shiki shiki-themes material-theme-lighter material-theme-lighter material-theme-palenight

function extendPages (callback: (pages: NuxtPage[]) => void): void

type NuxtPage = {
  name?: string
  path: string
  file?: string
  meta?: Record<string, any>
  alias?: string[] | string
  redirect?: RouteLocationRaw
  children?: NuxtPage[]
}

A function that will be called with the pages configuration. You can alter this array by adding, deleting, or modifying its elements. Note: You should modify the provided pages array directly, as changes made to a copied array will not be reflected in the configuration.

server engine. With Nitro, you can incorporate high-level logic directly into your configuration, which is useful for actions like redirects, proxying, caching, and appending headers to routes. This configuration works by associating route patterns with specific route settings.

A route pattern to match against.
A route configuration to apply to the matched route.

, it will override the existing route configuration.
Registers route middlewares to be available for all routes or for specific routes.

, it will override the existing middleware with the same name.
